importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the road crash in Uganda, which resulted in over 40 deaths, is significant as it marks a major incident of public safety failure and triggers national responses from government and emergency services.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The exact time of the crash, 00:15 local time, is critical as it indicates the severity of nighttime driving conditions and the timing of peak risk for overtaking behavior on a busy highway.

keyTakeAways: Forty-six people were killed in a head-on and side collision on the Kampala-Gulu Highway in Uganda, following a chain reaction caused by two buses attempting to overtake a lorry and car.
The initial death toll of 63 was revised down to 46, as police corrected for including unconscious victims who are now being treated.
Four vehicles were involved: two buses travelling in opposite directions, a lorry, and a car.
The crash occurred at 00:15 local time (21:15 GMT) on the Kampala-Gulu Highway, one of Uganda's busiest routes.
Police identified the cause as a bus attempting to overtake, which led to a head-on collision with a bus coming from the opposite direction, causing a chain reaction and multiple vehicle overturns.
The injured were taken to hospitals in Kiryandongo, a western town.

President Yoweri Museveni condemned the crash, expressed condolences, and announced that each bereaved family will receive five million Ugandan shillings ($1,430), and each injured person will receive one million shillings.
An investigation has been launched into the cause of the crash, with police urging motorists to avoid dangerous and careless overtaking, which remains a leading cause of crashes in Uganda.
The incident highlights ongoing traffic safety issues in Uganda and the need for improved enforcement and public awareness of road rules.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A major road crash on the Kampala-Gulu Highway in Uganda resulted in 46 fatalities after two buses attempting to overtake a lorry and car collided head-on in a chain reaction at 00:15 local time. The initial death toll of 63 was revised down after including unconscious victims. Police identified reckless overtaking as the root cause, and an investigation is underway. The injured were taken to hospitals in Kiryandongo. President Yoweri Museveni expressed condolences and announced financial aid for victims and injured parties. The incident underscores ongoing traffic safety concerns in Uganda, prompting authorities to urge caution and better enforcement of road rules.
title: Uganda road crash leaves more than 40 dead
